title: Emirati heritage tourism project set to be unveiled
text:
Emirati heritage tourism project set to be unveiled Article Friday, 4 September 2015 12:56 AM 
Marsa Al Seef will showcase the Emirati tradition of pearl diving as part of its tourism brief. 
Dubai-based holding company Meraas will unveil Marsa Al Seef, a tourism development located along Dubai Creek that aims to showcase Emirati heritage and culture next week. 
Construction of Marsa Al Seef has begun and the landmark project is set for completion in 2017, the company said in a statement. 
Meraas will display a model of the project at Cityscape Global 2015, the real estate event taking place at the Dubai World Trade Centre on September 8-10. 
Marsa Al Seef is conceptualised to combine modern lifestyle attractions and traditional cultural influences in a new development that will extend over 1.8km along Dubai Creek and serve as a showcase of Emirati heritage and culture. 
The project will feature an open-air museum and an amphitheatre, traditional souks, floating markets, art galleries and shops for Emirati handicrafts. 
With a 200-key heritage hotel, a 150-key upscale hotel, and a 200-room luxury hotel, Marsa Al Seef aims to revitalise the tourism experience around Dubai Creek. 
Abdul Wahab Al Halabi, CEO of Marsa Al Seef, said: "Meraas is committed to playing a vital role in developing key Dubai touristic projects in line with Dubai's Tourism Vision for 2020. 
"Marsa Al Seef is set to enrich Dubai's vibrant tourism industry by complementing and also rejuvenating the bustling trading locale along Dubai Creek as a hospitality, leisure and retail destination that will appeal to residents and tourists alike. 
"We are confident that the development will raise awareness and teach visitors about the rich history of the UAE and its people... Marsa Al Seef will host abra stations, dhow and private yacht moorings along its edge. Additionally, visitors will have the chance to experience the UAE way of life, and familiarise themselves with the traditions of pearl diving, fishing and boat building."
